headline.main: 2 U.S. Teams Leading in World Bridge

docs.snippet: All four American teams placed well today in the World Bridge championships.   In the Bermuda Bowl for open teams, the group led by James Cayne is fifth in its pool.The standings after 6 of 14 qualifying rounds are: 1st, South Africa, 101 points; 2
docs.lead_paragraph: All four American teams placed well today in the World Bridge championships. In the Bermuda Bowl for open teams, the group led by James Cayne is fifth in its pool.The standings after 6 of 14 qualifying rounds are: 1st, South Africa, 101 points; 2d, Argentina, 100; 3d, Indonesia, 94; 4th, Australia, 87; 5th, Cayne team, 86; 6th, Netherlands, 84; 7th, Venezuela, 81; 8th, France, 80.

headline.main: American Bridge Team Drops to Seventh Place

docs.snippet: One of the four American teams here seems headed for elimination in the Marlboro World Bridge Championships.   The team headed by James Cayne lost two matches and tied one in the Bermuda Bowl competition today. It is now seventh in its section, wit
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the four American teams here seems headed for elimination in the Marlboro World Bridge Championships. The team headed by James Cayne lost two matches and tied one in the Bermuda Bowl competition today. It is now seventh in its section, with the top four to qualify.

docs.snippet: Play was evenly balanced in the two finals at the Marlboro World Championships here today.         In the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams, the United States led Canada by the trivial margin of 1 imp after 64 deals of a scheduled 160. The American team co
docs.lead_paragraph: Play was evenly balanced in the two finals at the Marlboro World Championships here today. In the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams, the United States led Canada by the trivial margin of 1 imp after 64 deals of a scheduled 160. The American team consists of Nick Nickell of Raleigh, N.C., Dick Freeman of Atlanta, Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Fla., and Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas. The Canadian players are Joe Silver, Eric Kokish, Mark Molson and Boris Baran of Montreal and George Mittelman and Fred Gitelman of Toronto.

docs.lead_paragraph: Play was evenly balanced in the two finals at the Marlboro World Championships here today. In the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams, the United States led Canada by the trivial margin of 1 imp after 64 deals of a scheduled 160. The American team consists of Nick Nickell of Raleigh, N.C., Dick Freeman of Atlanta, Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Fla., and Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas. The Canadian players are Joe Silver, Eric Kokish, Mark Molson and Boris Baran of Montreal and George Mittelman and Fred Gitelman of Toronto.

docs.snippet: As I read Safire's sanitation of Hillary Clinton's speech, I wondered if he was going after the message or the messenger.
docs.lead_paragraph: As I read Safire's sanitation of Hillary Clinton's speech, I wondered if he was going after the message or the messenger.

docs.snippet: When Safire, the father of "nattering nabobs of negativism," can't criticize  content, he becomes a grumpy grammarian groping for grist for griping.      MILTON F. SHORE Silver Spring, Md.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Safire, the father of "nattering nabobs of negativism," can't criticize content, he becomes a grumpy grammarian groping for grist for griping. MILTON F. SHORE Silver Spring, Md.

docs.snippet: As I read Safire's sanitation of Hillary Clinton's speech, I wondered if he was going after the message or the messenger.          Let us remember that the spoken word often calls for different treatment than the written word: the application of Safi
docs.lead_paragraph: As I read Safire's sanitation of Hillary Clinton's speech, I wondered if he was going after the message or the messenger. Let us remember that the spoken word often calls for different treatment than the written word: the application of Safire's standards would diminish the fire and feel of almost every great oration.

docs.snippet: We are really tired of hearing William Safire hit at the Clintons as a means of atoning for his not supporting George Bush (On Language: "Hillary Speaks," Oct. 1).
docs.lead_paragraph: We are really tired of hearing William Safire hit at the Clintons as a means of atoning for his not supporting George Bush (On Language: "Hillary Speaks," Oct. 1).

docs.snippet: We are really tired of hearing William Safire hit at the Clintons as a means  of atoning for his not supporting George Bush (On Language: "Hillary Speaks," Oct. 1).          His carping at the First Lady's talk in China is a new low in nit-picking.
docs.lead_paragraph: We are really tired of hearing William Safire hit at the Clintons as a means of atoning for his not supporting George Bush (On Language: "Hillary Speaks," Oct. 1). His carping at the First Lady's talk in China is a new low in nit-picking.
